skills.name: Raise a number to the power of -1
Raise an integer to a negative integer power
Raise an integer to a positive unit fraction power
Multiplication law of indices with negative integer powers and the same base number
Multiplication and division law of indices with positive integer powers

explanations.A: Not quite! You have multiplied by -1 here, whereas this expression means we are looking for the value of 3 to the power of -1
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have read this as 3 subtract 1, whereas this expression means we are looking for the value of 3 to the power of -1
explanations.C: A power of -1 means the reciprocal, so 3⁻¹ = 1/3.
explanations.D: Nearly! You have found the negative reciprocal here, however the negative sign attached to the power does not make the final answer negative.

explanations.A: Not quite! You have multiplied by -1 here, whereas this expression means we are looking for the value of 5 to the power of -1
explanations.B: A power of -1 means the reciprocal, so 5⁻¹ = 1/5.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have read this as 5 subtract 1, whereas this expression means we are looking for the value of 5 to the power of -1
explanations.D: Nearly! You have found the negative reciprocal here, however the negative sign attached to the power does not make the final answer negative.

explanations.A: The power -2 is the same as finding the reciprocal and squaring. 4² = 16, so 4^-2 = 1/16.
explanations.B: Not quite! You have squared correctly, but the negative attached to the power doesn't make the answer negative, it means something else...
explanations.C: Not quite! You have correctly found the reciprocal, but a power of 2 does not mean multiply by 2. What does it mean instead?
explanations.D: Not quite! You have read this as 4 subtract 2 here, whereas this expression means we are looking for the value of 4 to the power of -2

explanations.A: Not quite! You have correctly found the reciprocal, but a power of 2 does not mean multiply by 2. What does it mean instead?
explanations.B: Not quite! You have squared correctly, but the negative attached to the power doesn't make the answer negative, it means something else...
explanations.C: The power -2 is the same as finding the reciprocal and squaring. 3⁻² = 1/3² = 1/9.
explanations.D: Not quite! You have read this as 3 subtract 2 here, whereas this expression means we are looking for the value of 3 to the power of -2

explanations.A: Not quite! You have multiplied the top powers and then divided by the denominator power. When we multiply / divide indices we need to remember to add / subtract the powers.
explanations.B: Almost! Think about your final step. You have have added the numerator powers correctly, but then divided by the power in the denominator. What's the rule for what we do to the powers when we divide?
explanations.C: We add the powers on the numerator and subtract the power on the denominator. This would give 2^(4 + 6 - 2) = 2^8 for our answer.
explanations.D: Have another think about the laws of indices we need to apply here. When we multiply / divide indices we need to remember to add / subtract the powers.

explanations.A: We add the powers on the top and subtract the powers on the bottom, so we get 2^(7 + 2 - 3) = 2^6.
explanations.B: Almost! Think about your final step. You have have added the numerator powers correctly, but then divided by the power in the denominator. What's the rule for what we do to the powers when we divide?
explanations.C: Not quite! Think about the rule we need to apply when simplifying the numerator here. What do we need to do to our powers when we multiply? It isn't multiply them...
explanations.D: Have another think about the laws of indices we need to apply here. When we multiply / divide indices we need to remember to add / subtract the powers.

explanations.A: Have another look. You have added ½ onto 64 here, whereas we are looking for the value of 64 raised to the power of ½
explanations.B: Raising something to the power of ½ is the same as finding the square root of the base number 64. √64 = 8.
explanations.C: Not quite! You have read this as 64 multiplied by ½, whereas we are looking for the value of 64 raised to the power of ½
explanations.D: Good try! I think you are confusing fractional indices with negative indices here, and have found 64 raised to the power of -1. What is the value of 64 raised to the power of ½?

explanations.A: Good try! I think you are confusing fractional indices with negative indices here, and have found 36 raised to the power of -1. What is the value of 36 raised to the power of ½?
explanations.B: Not quite! You have read this as 36 multiplied by ½, whereas we are looking for the value of 36 raised to the power of ½
explanations.C: Raising something to the power of ½ is the same as finding the square root of the base number 36. √36 = 6.
explanations.D: Have another look. You have added ½ onto 36 here, whereas we are looking for the value of 36 raised to the power of ½

explanations.A: Not quite! Have another look at the values of the indices we are adding here.
explanations.B: Not quite! You have multiplied the indices (powers) here, which we do when raising a power to another power, but not when simplifying multiplying. What happens to the indices when expressions with the same base are multiplied?
explanations.C: When expressions with the same base are multiplied, their indices are added. In this case, both base numbers are 7, so we can add the indices: 5 + (−2) = 5 − 2 = 3, giving a complete answer of 7³.
explanations.D: Have another think about the laws of indices we need to apply here. When expressions with the same base are multiplied, what happens to their indices?

explanations.A: Not quite! Have another look at the values of the indices we are adding here.
explanations.B: When expressions with the same base are multiplied, their indices are added. In this case, both base numbers are 8, so we can add the indices: 8 + (−5) = 8 − 5 = 3, giving a complete answer of 8³.
explanations.C: Not quite! You have multiplied the indices (powers) here, which we do when raising a power to another power, but not when simplifying multiplying. What happens to the indices when expressions with the same base are multiplied?
explanations.D: Have another think about the laws of indices we need to apply here. When expressions with the same base are multiplied, what happens to their indices?.
